name: Jade Pothos
climate: Jade Pothos thrives in tropical climates where temperatures are warm.
The plant can adapt to a range of humidity levels but prefers higher humidity climates.
It can tolerate lower temperatures but should not be exposed to freezing conditions.
It is hardy in USDA zones 10 through 12, indicative of warm climates.
sunlight: Jade Pothos prefers bright, indirect sunlight for optimal growth.
It can tolerate low light conditions but may grow more slowly.
Direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, causing damage to the plant.
East or north-facing windows provide ideal sunlight conditions.
watering: Water the Jade Pothos when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch.
Overwatering can cause root rot, so ensure proper drainage in the pot.
Underwatering can lead to wilting, but the plant tends to recover after watering.
Adjust watering frequency based on temperature and humidity levels.
soil: Jade Pothos requires well-draining potting soil to prevent root rot.
A mixture of peat moss, perlite or vermiculite often works well for this plant.
The soil should be rich in organic matter but not excessively dense.
Soil should retain some moisture without being waterlogged.
toxic: Toxic to cats and dogs if ingested, causing oral irritation and vomiting.
Contain calcium oxalate crystals that can irritate the digestive tract.
Symptoms of toxicity include drooling and difficulty swallowing in pets.
Keep out of reach of pets and children due to toxic properties.
extra_care_tip: Wipe leaves with a damp cloth to remove dust and help with photosynthesis.
Rotate the plant periodically to ensure even growth and leaf development.
Propagate easily through stem cuttings, which root quickly in water or soil.
Pinch back stems to encourage bushier growth and prevent legginess.
